awd_titl_txt: REU Site: University of California Santa Barbara's Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Ocean Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
A new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at University of California Santa Barbara (UCSB) will be established. The program will bring ten undergraduates to UCSB each summer for three years. Students will spend eight weeks conducting independent research projects with the support of USCB faculty mentors and participating in field trips and professional development activities.  They will receive stipends, housing and transportation. Independent research projects will focus on marine biology topics that integrate the study of physical and biological concepts. Students will make final presentations of their research to the community, including local fishermen and policy-makers.

The UCSB REU program is integrative, emphasizing the biological concepts that are core to marine systems, with a specific focus on the interaction of physical and biotic processes in coastal marine ecosystems such as kelp forests and the rocky intertidal zone. Students will have an opportunity to conduct research on the interaction of multiple abiotic factors and their effects on organisms.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to provide research experiences for undergraduates from colleges and universities across the US.  The project was focused on ocean global change biology and was a site Research Experience for Undergraduates on ocean global change biology (OGCB REU). For this activity, undergraduate students traveled to California and conducted a project for 8-weeks in a research laboratory at the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB).  Topics of student projects ranged from biological oceanography, the study of microbes in the ocean, the ecology of kelp forests, and the biology of marine fish and invertebrates.  In addition to doing research and learning more about the Pacific Ocean, students were able to develop science communication skills and presented their projects at a symposium at UCSB. Some students also attended national science meetings. The impact of the REU research experience was positive.  From our survey, most students were interested in attending graduate school both before and after the OGCB REU program.  Students reported that they felt that they had a better understanding for the steps needed to pursue a career that involves marine science after the program as compared to before. After having completing the REU program most students gained a better understanding of what every day-research work is like and developed more patience with the slow pace of research.  Overall, this site REU project served 24 undergraduates from across the nation.


Last Modified: 08/02/2023
Modified by: Gretchen E Hofmann
